In order to maintain the "poor man's Smalltalk" status they had to leave
out enough of the good stuff.  It wasn't bad enough for them that they
couldn't implement blocks.

=jason

On Mon, 2002-05-27 at 11:41, J. B. Rainsberger wrote: > Well, it is
sensible to consider the order when comparing lists.

For Lists, I agree; but often I use "Collection" when I do not want to
be 
concerned about the indices of elements.

> if you do not want that, or you have to compare different or unknown
> collections:
> 
> Set expected = new HashSet(expectedCollectionThatMightBeAList);
> Set actual = new HashSet(actualCollection);
> ...
> assertEquals(expected, actual);

...which works if there are no duplicate elements in either of the
original 
collections. If there are 7 Foos and 2 Bars in the one, there ought to
be 7 
and 2, respectively, in the other. Your approach does not check that.

What I really want is a Bag, dammit. Why didn't Java give us a Bag?!
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
